'''Rogue security software''' (or '''rogueware'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pandasecurity.com/img/enc/The%20Business%20of%20Rogueware.pdf|title=The Business of Rogueware|publisher=Panda Security|author=Sean-Paul Correll; Luis Corrons|date=2009-09-27|accessdate=2011-01-19}}</ref>) is a form of computer [[malware]] that deceives or misleads users into paying for the fake or simulated removal of malware, or that installs other malware.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eval.symantec.com/mktginfo/enterprise/white_papers/b-symc_report_on_rogue_security_software_exec_summary_20326021.en-us.pdf|publisher=Symantec|date=2009-10-28|title=Symantec Report on Rogue Security Software|accessdate=2010-04-15}}</ref> Rogue security software, in recent years (2008â2011), has become a growing and serious security threat in desktop computing.<ref name="microsoft-1">{{cite web|title = Microsoft Security Intelligence Report volume 6 (July - December 2008)|pages = 92|publisher = [[Microsoft]]|date = 2009-04-08|accessdate = 2009-05-02|url = http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=aa6e0660-dc24-4930-affd-e33572ccb91f&displaylang=en}}</ref>
== Propagation ==
Rogue security software mainly relies on [[social engineering (security)|social engineering]] ([[fraud]]) in order to defeat the security built into modern [[operating system]] and [[web browser|browser software]] and install itself onto victims' computers.<ref name="microsoft-1" /> A website may, for example, display a fictitious warning dialog stating that someone's machine is infected with a [[computer virus]], and encourage them through [[Social engineering (security)|social engineering]] to install or purchase [[scareware]] in the belief that they are purchasing genuine [[antivirus software]].
Most have a [[Trojan horse (computing)|Trojan horse]] component, which users are misled into installing. The Trojan may be disguised as: * A browser [[Plug-in (computing)|plug-in]] or extension (typically toolbar) * An image, screensaver or [[File archiver|archive file]] attached to an [[e-mail]] message * Multimedia codec required to play a certain [[video clip]] * Software shared on [[peer-to-peer]] networks<ref name="symantec-2">{{citation|first = Nishant|last = Doshi|date = 2009-01-19|accessdate = 2009-05-02|publisher = [[Symantec]]|title = Misleading Applications â Show Me The Money!|url = https://forums2.symantec.com/t5/blogs/blogprintpage/blog-id/security_risks/article-id/53}}</ref> * A free online malware scanning service<ref name="symantec-3">{{citation|first = Nishant|last = Doshi|date = 2009-01-21|accessdate = 2009-05-02|publisher = [[Symantec]]|title = Misleading Applications â Show Me The Money! (Part 2)|url = https://forums2.symantec.com/t5/blogs/blogprintpage/blog-id/security_risks/article-id/54}}</ref>
Some rogue security software, however, propagate onto users' computers as [[drive-by download]]s which exploit [[vulnerability (computing)|security vulnerabilities]] in web browsers, pdf viewers, or email clients to install themselves without any manual interaction.<ref name="symantec-2" /><ref name="blog_adobe">{{cite web |url=http://blogs.adobe.com/psirt/2009/12/new_adobe_reader_and_acrobat_v.html |title=News Adobe Raeder and Acrobat Vulnerability |publisher=blogs.adobe.com |accessdate=25 November 2010}}</ref>
More recently, malware distributors have been utilizing [[search engine optimization|SEO poisoning]] techniques by pushing infected URLs to the top of search engine results about recent news events. People looking for articles on such events on a search engine may encounter results that, upon being clicked, are instead redirected through a series of sites<ref name="fsecure"> {{Citation | last = Chu | first = Kian | last2 = Hong | first2 = Choon | title = Samoa Earthquake News Leads To Rogue AV | publisher = [[F-Secure]] | date = 2009-09-30 | url = http://www.f-secure.com/weblog/archives/00001779.html | accessdate = 2010-01-16}}</ref> before arriving at a landing page that says that their machine is infected and pushes a download to a "trial" of the rogue program.<ref name="eweek">{{Citation | last = Hines | first = Matthew | title = Malware Distributors Mastering News SEO | publisher = [[eWeek]] | date = 2009-10-08 | url = http://securitywatch.eweek.com/seo/malware_distributors_mastering_news_seo.html | accessdate = 2010-01-16}}</ref><ref name="sc-magazine">{{Citation | last = Raywood | first = Dan | title = Rogue anti-virus prevalent on links that relate to Haiti earthquake, as donors encouraged to look carefully for genuine sites | publisher = SC Magazine | date = 2010-01-15 | url = http://www.scmagazineuk.com/rogue-anti-virus-prevalent-on-links-that-relate-to-haiti-earthquake-as-donors-encouraged-to-look-carefully-for-genuine-sites/article/161431/ | accessdate = 2010-01-16}}</ref> A 2010 study by [[Google]] found 11,000 domains hosting fake anti-virus software, accounting for 50% of all malware delivered via internet advertising.<ref>{{cite journal|publisher=[[Google]]|url=http://krebsonsecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/leet10.pdf|date=2010-04-13|accessdate=2010-11-18|author=Moheeb Abu Rajab and Luca Ballard|title=The Nocebo Effect on the Web: An Analysis of Fake Anti-Virus Distribution}}</ref>
== Operation ==
Once installed, the rogue security software may then attempt to entice the user into purchasing a service or additional software by: * Alerting the user with the fake or simulated detection of malware or [[pornography]].<ref name="ftc-1">{{citation|url = http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/edu/pubs/consumer/alerts/alt121.shtm|title = "Free Security Scan" Could Cost Time and Money|publisher = [[Federal Trade Commission]]|date = 2008-12-10|accessdate = 2009-05-02}}</ref> * Displaying an animation simulating a system crash and reboot.<ref name="microsoft-1" /> * Selectively disabling parts of the system to prevent the user from uninstalling them. Some may also prevent anti-malware programs from running, disable automatic [[system software]] updates and block access to websites of anti-malware vendors. * Installing actual malware onto the computer, then alerting the user after "detecting" them. This method is less common as the malware is likely to be detected by legitimate [[Malware#Anti-malware programs|anti-malware programs]]. * Altering system registries and security settings, then "alerting" the user.
Developers of rogue security software may also entice people into purchasing their product by claiming to give a portion of their sales to a charitable cause. The rogue Green antivirus, for example, claims to donate $2 to an environmental care program for each sale made.<ref>[http://cantalktech.com/2009/05/16/remove-green-antivirus-2009/ CanTalkTech - Fake Green AV disguises as security software with a cause]</ref>
Some rogue security software overlaps in function with [[scareware]] by also: * Presenting offers to fix urgent performance problems or perform essential housekeeping on the computer.<ref name="ftc-1" /> * Scaring the user by presenting authentic-looking pop-up warnings and security alerts, which may mimic actual system notices.<ref name="microsoft-3">{{cite web |url=http://tech.yahoo.com/blog/null/107193 |title=SAP at a crossroads after losing $1.3B verdict |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=25 November 2010}}</ref> These are intended to use the trust that the user has in vendors of legitimate security software.<ref name="microsoft-1" />
Sanction by the FTC and the increasing effectiveness of anti-malware tools since 2006 have made it difficult for [[spyware]] and [[adware]] distribution networksâalready complex to begin with<ref>{{citation|title = Testimony of Ari Schwartz on "Spyware"|publisher = [[Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation]]|date = 2005-05-11|url = http://www.cdt.org/testimony/20050511schwartzspyware.pdf}}</ref>âto operate profitably.<ref>{{cite web|title = Zango goes titsup: End of desktop adware market|publisher = [[The Register]]|date = 2009-04-11|accessdate = 2009-05-05|url = http://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/04/21/zango|first = John|last = Leyden}}</ref> Malware vendors have turned instead to the simpler, more profitable [[business model]] of rogue security software, which is targeted directly at users of [[Personal computer|desktop computers]].<ref name="symantec-1">{{citation|url = https://forums2.symantec.com/t5/blogs/blogprintpage/blog-id/grab_bag/article-id/5|title = Deceptonomics: A Glance at The Misleading Application Business Model|first = Dave|last = Cole|date = 2006-07-03|publisher = [[Symantec]]|accessdate = 2009-05-02}}</ref>
Rogue security software is often distributed through highly lucrative [[affiliate network]]s, in which affiliates supplied with Trojan kits for the software are paid a fee for every successful installation, and a commission from any resulting purchases. The affiliates then become responsible for setting up infection vectors and distribution infrastructure for the software.<ref name="symantec-4">{{citation|first = Nishant|last = Doshi|date = 2009-01-27|accessdate = 2009-05-02|publisher = [[Symantec]]|title = Misleading Applications â Show Me The Money! (Part 3)|url = https://forums2.symantec.com/t5/blogs/blogprintpage/blog-id/security_risks/article-id/55}}</ref> An investigation by security researchers into the Antivirus XP 2008 rogue security software found just such an affiliate network, in which members were grossing commissions upwards of $[[US dollar|USD]]150,000 over 10 days, from tens of thousands of successful installations.<ref name="secureworks">{{citation|title = Rogue Antivirus Dissected - Part 2|first = Joe|last = Stewart|date = 2008-10-22|publisher = SecureWorks|url = http://www.secureworks.com/research/threats/rogue-antivirus-part-2/?threat=rogue-antivirus-part-2}}</ref>
== Law enforcement ==
In December 2006, the Washington [[Attorney General]] announced that it had reached settlement in a suit against Secure Computer LLC, the [[White Plains, New York|White Plains]]-based vendor of the Spyware Cleaner rogue security software, under the Computer Spyware Act passed by the [[Washington State Legislature]] in 2005. Secure Computer, under [[consent decree]], agreed to pay more than $75,000 in restitution to consumers.<ref>{{citation|date = 2006-12-04|title = Attorney General McKenna Announces $1 Million Settlement in Washingtonâs First Spyware Suit|url = http://www.atg.wa.gov/pressrelease.aspx?&id=5926|publisher = Washington State Office of the Attorney General|accessdate = 2009-05-02}}</ref>
In December 2008, the [[United States District Court for the District of Maryland|US District Court for Maryland]]âat the request of the [[Federal Trade Commission|FTC]]âissued a [[Injunction|restraining order]] against Innovative Marketing Inc, a [[Kiev]]-based firm producing and marketing the rogue security software products [[WinFixer]], [[WinAntivirus]], [[DriveCleaner]], [[ErrorSafe]], and [[XP Antivirus]].<ref>{{citation|url = http://www.ftc.gov/os/caselist/0723137/081203innovativemrktgtro.pdf|publisher = [[United States District Court for the District of Maryland]]|date = 2008-12-03|title = Ex Parte Temporary Restraining Order RDB08CV3233|accessdate = 2009-05-02}}</ref> The company and its US-based web host, ByteHosting Internet Hosting Services LLC, had their assets frozen, were barred from using [[Domain name system|domain names]] associated with those products and any further advertisement or false representation.<ref>{{citation|title = Court Halts Bogus Computer Scans|publisher = [[Federal Trade Commission]]|accessdate = 2009-05-02|date = 2008-12-10|url = http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2008/12/winsoftware.shtm|first = Betsy|last = Lordan}}</ref>
Law enforcement has also exerted pressure on banks to shut down merchant gateways involved in processing rogue security software purchases. In some cases, the high volume of [[credit card]] [[chargeback]]s generated by such purchases has also prompted processors to take action against rogue security software vendors.<ref>{{citation|title = Rogue Antivirus Distribution Network Dismantled|url = http://voices.washingtonpost.com/securityfix/2009/03/sunlight_disinfects_rogue_anti.html|first = Brian|last = Krebs|date = 2009-03-20|newspaper = [[Washington Post]]|accessdate = 2009-05-02}}</ref>
